Reviews.Title: Not Quite Perfect, But Close
Reviews.Author: Philip R. Heath "Gadgets, Music, & Books"
Reviews.Content: The Good:+ Extra Smooth, Fast Navigation+ Video Playback+ Music Playback+ Games+ Good Browser Experience+ Long Battery Life+ Micro-USB Charging Port (Finally!)+ Intel Processor+ Priced Right+ Plenty of Case OptionsThe Bad:- Lots of Bloatware- Feels CheapOverall:  The materials might feel cheap, but ASUS gets the rest of the table experience right this time.Design:  I guess to get the rest of the experience at this price, ASUS had to compromise on design materials.  The back casing of the ASUS MeMO Pad FHD 10 makes most netbooks feel like they were made of prime materials by comparison.  There's no way to sugar coat it.  The MeMO Pad feels like a toy compared to the brushed aluminum on the Transformer Pad Infinity.  It is also not the thinnest or lightest tablet compared to the likes of the Sony Xperia Z.  However, this is where my gripes essentially end with the MeMO Pad.Setup:  The instructions recommended a minimum of 8 hours charging, and I dropped mine on the charger and left it overnight.  This is a bit of a buzzkill for the excitement of a new tablet, but it is worth it.  You will benefit in long-term battery performance over the life of the tablet.  Other than that, ASUS has an easy to follow guided process that even first time users will be able to follow without issue.  There was a firmware update available, and I installed it before proceeding.  From this point forward, I experience boot-up times of about 35-40 seconds.  It's not the fastest, but it is vastly better than the Transformer Pad Infinity.Video Playback:  This is the punch line for a "Full HD" tablet, right?  Well, ASUS did a great job.  I fed the MeMO Pad some eye candy in the form of Thor and Beowulf from Netflix.  I have always thought that the throne room scene at the beginning of Thor was striking, and the colors were as rich as ever.  Beowulf is a relatively new entrant on Netflix, but it came through in all its glory as well.  One other Netflix improvement is in the actual navigation of the app itself.  Every other tablet I've used (Acer Iconia A100, ASUS Transformer Pad Infinity, and Sony Xperia Z) had poor, choppy navigation when scrolling through movies.  I am very pleased to say that this is not the case on the MeMO Pad.  Perhaps it is the new Intel chip that makes the difference.  This starts a trend of performance over design.Music Playback:  While it is definitely bigger than your phone (or dedicated mp3 player), the target use for the MeMO Pad is still with headphones.  The speakers are sufficient for watching video or playing games, but they lack the bass required to provide an enjoyable, balanced music listening session.  However, I used both my Monster Diesel Vektr (corded) and Plantronics BackBeat Go 2 (Bluetooth) headphones, and the experience is quite good.  If for some reason you don't already have a device to play mp3s, this will get the job done.  The Play Music app is the default for local music play, and both it and the Amazon MP3 apps can play from the cloud.Gaming:  Call me old school, but I love pinball.  I have been a fan of Zen Pinball since it came on my Acer tablet a couple of years ago.  The HD screen makes tables such as The Avengers pop visually, but the gameplay was smoother than I have experienced on my other tablets.  There was never a hitch or a jerk in the display.  While this is far from the most taxing game out there, I noticed a surprising improvement over the Transformer Pad Infinity.  The performance over design trend continues.Navigation:  I mentioned this earlier about Netflix, but the smooth navigation carries over into all aspects of the MeMO Pad.  Both the app tray and Chrome are snappy and smooth.  In the past, I have always been a bit envious of iPad owners because everything flowed so effortlessly.  This tablet is the first Android offering that has performed in the same zip code as the iPad.  I don't know how to account for it with certainty, but I do know that this is the first tablet I've had with the new Intel Clover Trail+ chip.  Whatever the cause, it's about time!Other:  The battery life on the MeMO Pad is as advertised.  The first charge lasted for three days of intermittent use.  ASUS finally went away from the proprietary charging port to micro-USB.  It is so nice not to have to worry about carrying around my one and only charger for my tablet.  It will just work with the one myriad of micro-USB chargers I have at home, work, in the car, etc.  You might accuse me of burying the lead on this, but all this goodness comes at a substantial discount over the Transformer Pad Infinity prices.  The only thing the Infinity has over the MeMO is the brushed aluminum case.  (All apologies to the "Dock" owners, but that is a component destined for failure from stress/wear and tear.)Complaints:  The list is pretty short.  I've already mentioned the cheap feel of the back panel.  The other thing that I don't like is common to most tablets - lots of bloatware.  Perhaps I am the outlier on this, but I just can't imagine that users are chomping at the bit to use the one off ASUS apps over things that are more generally available.  The only way to avoid them is to go with a "pure Android" device from Google, and I guess I can't be too harsh.  Since Android 4.0, you can disable and hide unwanted apps.  I just wish the tablet and computer makers would stop it.Conclusion:  Although I wish it had nicer material for the back panel, I can't take exception with much else about this tablet from ASUS.  Whatever it is that they've changed since the "Transformer" line; it works.  This tablet is strong to quite strong.  You get your money's worth, and I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Why I chose Asus Memo Pad FHD 10
Reviews.Author: Gabriel Sala
Reviews.Content: I was looking for replacement for my Ipad 1. My tablet usage scenario involves a lot of browsing, book reading, some movie watching and very light gaming.After some research I bought Asus Memo Pad FHD 10.It is a 10" tablet wiht 1920x1200 resolution which puts is above Galaxy Tab 3 and most of the tablets that feature 1280x800,on par with Sony Xperia Tablet Z and below Google(Samsung) Nexus 10 and Apple iPad.Please note, that while Sony Xperia Tablet Z has the same resoluton, the Sony screen is brighter and the color space is closer to RGB than on Memo Pad.Memo Pad FHD 10 runs Intel z2560 CPU based on x86 architecture while all other tablets use ARM architecture CPU.This implies that is really difficult to compare the performance, since some operations are faster and other opeations are slower than in ARM based CPUs.For example, the MemoPad Antutu test results are better than Nexus 10, the Sun spyder tests results  are better than on Sony Xperia Tablet Z, whilethe Geekbench puts Asus Memopad below last year Tegra3.Also, some application that use native ARM code or mixed code may have problems with this product.Even if Intel handles the code translation with the magic libhoudini.so, the translation is not perfect and may affect the performance and stability.Fortunately, it happens with very few applications.Why I chose Asus Memo Pad over Ipad 4:- I decided to switch from Apple to Android ecosystem.- Ipad has just 1Gb of RAM. My fear is that in 2 years the retina resolution Ipad4 will crash with 1Gbas my current Ipad one constantly crashes with 256Mb of RAM. (The crashes started after IOS upgrades, and I can't downgrade the OS version)- Ipad 4 is more expensiveWhy I chose Asus Memo Pad over Sony Tablet Z:- All reviews point that the battery life is lowest among  the competitors.- My everyday use scenario involves  a lot of browsing and Tablet Z scores pretty low on browser related tests.- According some message boards and reviews, Tablet Z runs hotter (> 100F) even in simple scenarios.- TabletZ is ~$150 more expensive.- The TabletZ beauty and lightweight design will not be appreciated with a case or cover.Why I chose Asus Memo Pad over Nexus 10:- Nexus 10 doesn't have microSD slot, so the 32Gb version is mandatory, this makes Nexus 10 ~$80 more expensive (as of today).and still I have my storage space limited.- While 2Gbs are enough for 1920x1200, there are some reports of crashes due to not enough memory in Nexus 10.- I don't like Nexus 10 design.- According some message boards and reviews, the Nexus 10 tends to heat up considerably in some circumstances.Also there are some complains about random freezes and reboots.What you should choose:If you're happy with Apple ecosystem, don't want to spend time learning android, and don't mind paying few $$$ more - get an Ipad.If you want the best colors, best design or you plan to use your tablet outdoors - check the Sony Tablet Xperia ZIf you need the highest resolution, but by some reason don't like the IPad - Nexus 10 is your choice.I expect that in few months new models will be released making this review partially obsolete.

Reviews.Title: be careful, some apps are not compatible
Reviews.Author: melonboy123
Reviews.Content: This is a good tablet, well designed and is very fast. I also saw the Samsung galaxy tab 3 10.1. This tablet is much more clear that galaxy tab 3. However, the problem is, this tablet is empowered by Intel atom processor. Some apps are currently not compatible with it, because most apps are design for ARM processor. So you will find that you cannot install Firefox and adobe air. If you can sacrifice some apps you like, this is overall a good tablet at a reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: Coming from an HP TouchPad running Android, this thing is awesome
Reviews.Author: Juniorverse1
Reviews.Content: Whenever I get a new Android device, I usually root it and install a custom ROM, CyanogenMod.  I like the custom user interface on this tablet so much, I don't even feel the need to install a different ROM.  While it doesn't have all of the features of CyanogenMod, it does have a bunch of unique features that other ROMs do not.=== Look and Feel ===I had an HP TouchPad that I installed Android 4.2 on, and this tablet blows it away.  The screen is bright and the resolution is high.  Text is easy to read, and images and video look terrific.  It is light and easy to hold, although I decided to use a case (the VSTN Multi-Stand PU Leather Cover Case with Hand Strap and Card Holder).  The tablet even responds to the cover by sleeping when the cover is closed and waking up when the cover opens.  The images and video from the camera look great.=== The User Interface ===There is an extra button on the bottom of the screen that pops up a menu with a number of mini-apps that each open in their own draggable window.  Each works like a standard window that can remain visible while other apps are being viewed.  These mini-apps include:- Calculator- Audio Wizard (for selecting presets like Music, Movie, Gaming, Speech, and Recording)- A full dictionary, allowing you to look up words and show their definitions, listen to an audio example of how to pronounce the word, and a link to search for it on Wikipedia.- A video player- A complete unit converter, like for converting inches to millimeters- A simple countdown clock- A stopwatch- A compass- A mini-browser- A mini-calendar and e-mail window that links to your existing calendar and e-mail accounts- BuddyBuzz, a mini-window that you can link to your social media accounts withThe notification drawer that pulls down at the top of the screen has a bunch of controls in it.  From left to right:- On/Off for Wi-Fi, Power SmartSaving, Instant Dictionary (see below), Bluetooth, GPS, Sound.- A slider for brightness (with a toggle for auto-brightness)- A shortcut to Wi-Fi settings, sound settings (more on this later), wireless display settings (Miracast), and general settings.- The standard Android notifications.=== ASUS Apps ===I was surprised at the number and quality of some of the ASUS apps that come pre-installed.  These include:- AOLink, a media browser that can access your DLNA devices and your own ASUS cloud storage.- App Backup and App Locker- ASUS Artist, a fun little painting program with a variety of pens, airbrushes, backgrounds, etc.- ASUS Splendid, a tool for calibarting the colors on your tablet- ASUS Studio, a photo album organizer- ASUS To-Do, a task manager that also links to your Google account- AudioWizard (previously mentioned)- BuddyBuzz (previously mentioned)- Dictionary- My BitCast - a tool for organizing notes and photos using an ASUS cloud account- My Library, an e-reader- Parental Lock - a parental control app- People, a contact manager that links to your Google account- PowerSaver, a tool for automatically conserving energy which is customizable- Story, a simple storyboard editor that allows you to add photos, maps, and text and then share the image using a number of tools or your e-mail- SuperNote Lite, a tool for editing mini notepads including text, images, and even your handwriting.=== Summary ===I highly recommend this tablet.  If you have any questions about it, please ask and I will do my best to answer them!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Large Tablet 16GB computer with intel plays movies great, and speech mode instead of typing.
Reviews.Author: Enchanted  In  Dixie "Enchanted"
Reviews.Content: Large Android Jellybean tablet that is touch friendly with excellent performance..  Has all you ever need in a compact computer tablet.  Comes with basics charger and instructions.  Before use, it is good idea to put a screen protector on it.  Came with enough charge to set up. It gave the prompts and took about 15 minutes to do my set ups.  I then charged 5 hours and was ready to go.I love that this is a 16GB Tablet which is big enough to hold lots of information, and makes a nice little computer for every day use.  It easy to sync to all my other devices and get my information. I signed into my email accounts and have icon, that I can now touch and go directly to the emails.Touch Screen; 10.1"  WUXGA (19201200):  Screen  is actually 8 1/2 " X 5 1/2"  viewing area, as it has a 1" boarder all around.  It works great for those of us who need reading glasses, but unfortuantely will not fit in most purses.  So for more portability I prefer my  ASUS MeMOPad HD 7-Inch 16 GB Tablet, (ME173X-A1-BL)smaller Asus 7". see why : http://www.amazon.com/review/R3RQ23WYI2M48T/ref=cm_cr_pr_cmt?ie=UTF8&ASIN;=B00E0EY7Z6&linkCode;=&nodeID;=&tag;=#wasThisHelpfulSpeak and it types for you. Easy to use speech mode to look up websites or add to this review. It is awesome to be able to talk, and let this computer write this review.Movies and music: INTEL Clover Trail Plus Z2560 (1.6GHz) Dual Core ;  INTEL CloverTrail Plus Z2560; 2GB DDR2; SGX544MP2  provides great viewing. The screen is greatfor watching movies and is very clear and detailed.  You need to get a stand, if you do not want to watch flat. The 2 speakers on back do provide great clairty and sound.See my pic above of Snowball. Camera / video is so easy to use. 1.2MP Front & 5MP Rear. It will take a photo from the back camera , or touch the flip on screen it can be in mirror and take a pic of you.  This is really handy. It has built in mic also,  so if you want to do face to face video call on this tablet computer like with skype you can, or use video camera funciton to make movies.Love the note pad function. It is so easy to make my grocery / shopping list or any list for that matter.  You can write with your finger. Great for reminders.  My daughter got me a 2" soft end static pin in bubble gum machine at grocery store that hooks in the earphone jack. It works great on the touch screen, when I do not want to use my finger.Remember to add virus software, I choose the Avast for mobile devices and it recognized the tablet immediately. I downloaded the free Avast, and went on to choose the free avast storage back up, so that I can have my photos backed up for free, as a complement to the Asus backup.Pre Installed appsAmazon kindle Aolink App back up webstorage App locker  ASUS Artist  ASUSsplendid ASUS Studio  ASUS to-do  Audio Wizard Browser  Buddy Buzz Calculator  Calendar Camera  Chrome  Clock  Dictionary  Downloads  Email  File Manager  Gallery  Gmail  Google Google settings  Google+  Instant dictionary  Local  local maps  Messenger  Movie studio  MybitCast  My Library  Navigation  Parental Lock  People  Play books  Play Magazine  Play Movies & TV  Play Music  Play store  Power saver  press reader  settings  setup wizard  Sound Recorder  story  superNote Lite  talk  voice Search  webstore  You Tube  ZinoEasy to download apps. Just connect to wifi and go on a search. I got the free daily amazon game and it is so cool.  All are touch friendly and work great.Ports :  Head phone / Mic-in; Micro USB;  Micro HDMI; Micro SD (SDHC) a small micro disc port. NO DISC INCLUDED.MeMO Pad FHD 10 (White); White Color of unit is the back color.Love the 1 year North American Warranty.

Reviews.Title: Best Bang For Your Buck On The Planet
Reviews.Author: RaiderWill
Reviews.Content: If you want a Tablet that does it all the 32Gb MeMO Pad FHD 10 has no equal.. I've owned Tab 3's,  Nexus-7 2013, Note 8.0.. they just don't match up.. FORGET Synthetic Benchmarks.. Don't let websites suck you in with numbers.. this Tablet kicks ass. Run either Nova or Holo launcher which allows you to speed up transitions if you need to make the Tablet seem snappier..HDMI Out works flawlessly and allows you to keep continuous charge supplied to the Tablet while viewing the Tablet on your Big Screen T.V. 1920 x 1200 is true HD Resolution and the Tablet is Razor Sharp.. I suggest you download Dolphin Browser from the playstore it runs MUCH smoother than Chrome..(Don't know why year after year Google's own Browser still stutters)The weight is average for this class of Tablet the rear is really grippy and feels nice even holding it for long periods.Asus is good with updates so I fully expect this this Tablet to get upgraded to Android 4.3 and possibly Android 4.4 early next year.. Please don't even consider the 3 Rating Review.. That is someone that is upset there are not Custom ROM's available.. If you know what that is... this Tablet Especially the 32 Gb verison checks ALL the boxes and is a Great Buy @ $300.00 with more than enough power for demanding 3D gaming, movies and anything else you can throw at it :)

Reviews.Title: Wonderful Tablet
Reviews.Author: W. G. boyd
Reviews.Content: I was eager to purchase a new tablet before a long vacation. Traditionally I tote my laptop and after some consideration I realized a large tablet would suit my needs and be much more portable. I had my eye on the predecessor to this model which was inferior related to the resolution. I also didn't feel like shelling out big bucks for a new iPad; so for me, the middle ground of a mid-priced tablet with good specs on paper fit the bill.  It arrived in a couple days, just before my trip, so I promptly hit the GooglePlay store and loaded it up.Battery LifeDuring a 12 hour flight I was able to watch four movies back to back. I played some dots, listened to music and read content that I had saved prior.  While USB outlets were available on the plane, I didn't need to plug in.  I arrived with 30-something percent left. IMHO battery life is excellent.DisplayI read that some folks didn't like the display due to it not being as "bright" as iPad retina and the Nexus 10.  Well, honestly, I keep the brightness on this somewhere between 25 and 50 percent and it's absolutely great.  It's very vivid and cris-pity clear.  Again, even though I was looking to be critical, it's impossible.  This tablet display is very very nice.OverallSince my trip, I read and monitor Twitter nightly during the prime time shows I watch and enjoy the easy use. I'm always using it browse the web and relegated my laptop to the desk for tasks like Photoshop only! The FHD 10 is very lightweight and easy to hold. The sound is GREAT when watching youtube video or listening to music.  I have not tried Chromecast yet, but that's on my list.  Streaming video is smooth and error-free,  Web browsing gave me some concern initially because Chrome was soooo very laggy.  However after an update to Chrome, the experience is fantastic.  I am very very happy with my purchase.  The MeMO FHD 10 is fast, lightweight and looks great.  I have had zero issues with it and prefer the GooglePlay experience more than my iPhone and iTunes experience related to ease of use and content.  I'm not a "gamer" so I can't comment on that... but so far all my apps, social media stuff and web surfing are fantastic.I'm happy to answer questions etc if you have any prior to purchasing.

Reviews.Title: Excellent tablet
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research and flip-flopping before deciding on this tablet.  I wish that I hadn't, because I love it!The Good:The screen is nice and crisp.  I hear complaints about brightness, but I have no issues with it.  The auto brightness can be a little strange, but other than that it is fine.  The images look good and the color is not over saturated.  The size is great.  Another complaint I see is that there is too much bezel.  I have no issue with this either, as it lets me hold the tablet with my fingers getting in the way of what I am actually trying to see.The price is AWESOME.  I looked and looked for other tablets.  I could find used tablets for decent price, but wasn't so sure.  I have seen a couple of refurbs that might have been nice, but I just couldn't pull the trigger.  Getting a brand new device with a warranty makes me feel a lot better.  For the price you get a great deal here!  For a 10 inch tablet at this resolution you're usually spending much more.The keyboard.  I know it sounds weird, but I love this keyboard.  This has sold me on the typing experience.  This is an Asus keyboard, it differs slightly from the Android stock keyboard.  Providing the row with numbers is a boon and the layout is actually quite nice when you're using @'s and .com's.The speakers sound very nice.  When I saw videos or read reviews I kind of blew it off.  After using them, I am kind of impressed.  Don't get me wrong, you aren't throwing out your sound system and replacing it with this, but these are some of the best sounding tablet speakers I've heard.  They weren't super tinny and the mid range wasn't muddy and gross.  Not a lot of deep bass response, but I didn't expect much.  I was please with how it handled by old school gangster rap (NWA and Ice Cube) as well as 90's hard rock (Alice in Chains and White Zombie).The performance is actually much better than I anticipated.  Most of the reviews of this tablet pit it against some of the best tablets out there, which may not really be fair.  A lot of the reviews also use benchmarks that I'm not entirely sure can make full use of the Intel CPU powering this beast.  I have yet to see a real stutter on the device.  I have noticed a hiccup here or there when downloading or installing a lot of stuff at once while I was loading it up, but nothing else slows it down.  I've played a handful of games, browsed web pages and and scrolled through the screens countless times now.  The web browsing experience is actually remarkably smooth.  It is lightning fast and I was kind of shocked by it's responsiveness.  Web browsing is one of the things that this tablet does best, honestly.  With the speed at which it tears through the internet supported by the gorgeous screen and it's size and resolution... how can this not be a win?The Bad:The battery life has been kind of on the crappy side.  I understand that I am hammering away at this thing, but when I sit it down at night I expect that when I pick it up that it shouldn't have drained 20% while I was asleep.  Granted, there may be one of the apps that I've installed causing the issue, it is still frustrating.  I am sure that once I regulate my usage that the battery life will get even better.  I fooled with it nearly 12 hours today off and on and move it from 79% to 23?% before I tossed it on the charger.  The charger that comes with it, btw, seems to do the best job charging it.  Even a Note 2 charger wasn't pumping out the juice to move this badboy today.I am still skeptical about the support that this Intel CPU is going to get.  There is no real mod community and no one is developing ROMs for this device.  The method for rooting it is very limited.  While I've only run into one application that won't run on this tablet, I assume there are others.  I want Intel to do well in this space, though.  Since the developing community doesn't see a lot of interest, I wonder what I can expect in terms of updates from ASUS.  With a 4.4 release coming any day now, I would like the security of knowing that I can take advantage of some of these features.  If I can't get it from Cyanogen, I'd like to hope that waiting a little bit extra could score me an update from the manufacturer.Overall:This tablet kills it!  As long as you go in understanding that this IS NOT a top tier Android tablet.  It isn't going to be the fastest super tablet ever.  This is a capable tablet with a good looking screen that comes in a nice size that is insanely affordable.  I think this tablet is better than the top tier of last year in a lot of ways, but won't be competing with the brand new top end tablets of this year.  I got this to watch YouTube videos with my young son while we cuddle on the couch, to watch some Netflix when I don't wanna be in front of the TV, and to play Hearthstone when I'm supposed to be working (via Splashtop).  This tablet does all of that and more.I wish there were more actual accessories for this tablet.  Finding actual stuff for it or to fit it is no easy task.  For the price, though, I can't complain.  Most tablets exist as a niche.

Reviews.Title: good ipad alternative, especially considering cost difference.
Reviews.Author: mike gallagher
Reviews.Content: I purchased this after reluctantly giving up my ipad3. I was thinking about getting the new iPad but then I started seeing pricing for the 64GB versions (of even the iPad mini), OUTRAGEOUS. I have a ton of music and movies, which this screws people like me as a 'power user' so Apple really sticks it to you for the extra memory (which honestly, is really cheap). Even @64GB, I had less than 10GB left! It is not cool at all that for a small amount of memory (cost wise) that they stick it to you so hard for 64GB and I think the new 128GB will be completely out of this park expensive. Anyways, the cost was almost triple the cost of this unit. My major requirements was at least 64GB and something running at least the latest version of android OS (I've used Jellybean on multiple cell phones and it's pretty cool).  I had given a droid tablet a try before I got my iPad 3 and was not impressed (motorola brand) and returned to store, that did feel cheap. This time, with Jelly Bean shipping on the unit, it's not the same, not even close to same experience. If, like me, you're not happy with the IOS 7 changes, this is a good time to give android a shot (even if you have before). This unit is great, I disagree that the device feels cheap, it doesn't at all. The sound is really good for a tablet device as is the touchscreen. I did find issues with the light sensor to be a bit crazy like others had noted, but that's easy to disable and manually manipulate. Usually with tablets you're not moving like you are with a cell phone. The colors and brightness of the lcd, no complaints here. The only slight issue I saw was the onscreen keyboard is not the best but I'll survive to save as much as I did getting this unit. Here's my favorite part, this device supports microsd cards up to at least 64GB, so now my tablet isn't 64GB, it's **96GB***. I took my itunes directory and put it on a microsd card and plug it in, bam, done now my entire library is moved. Overall, I think this is a great tablet that you should consider prior to spend 2-3times for apple products.

Reviews.Title: A great Android tablet and iPad Retina alternative
Reviews.Author: Jerry Jackson Jr.
Reviews.Content: The ASUS MeMo Pad 10 FHD is a fantastic Android tablet for those who want something similar to the iPad with Retina display but running Android instead. The screen isn't quite as bright as the latest iPad with the brightness turned all the way up (so it might be very difficult to see the screen under direct sunlight) and the screen on my ASUS MeMo Pad 10 FHD needed to be adjusted using the included app that lets you increase the color saturation. However, this IPS display has GREAT viewing angles and has essentially the same image quality as the iPad.The Memo Pad FHD also has a microSD card slot so you can add additional storage to your tablet ... something the iPad and most alternative Android tablets don't have.The performance of the Intel processor and graphics are "class leading" but I never had any problems or significant lag when viewing websites, video, playing games, running productivity apps for work or editing photos on this tablet.I will say that the tablet is a little bigger than some other 10-inch tablets (like the iPad) because of the screen ratio so it barely fits inside some "universal" tablet cases designed for 10-inch tablets.I found that the battery life varies dramatically depending on the apps you're running. I get 8 to 10 hours of battery life with this tablet when I'm mostly just browsing websites and watching a couple of short video clips on YouTube. If I play a bunch of games that have to connect with servers (because they're multiplayer games) then the battery life might only be 4+ hours before I get the alert message that I need to plug in the charger.In short, I would highly recommend this tablet to anyone who is looking for an Android tablet with a great screen and good features. It's not an iPad ... but some people consider that to be a good thing.

Reviews.Title: Impressive: quality build, lightweight, quick, good speakers and interface, very good not great screen.
Reviews.Author: austin_Larry
Reviews.Content: I had no idea what to expect with this tablet. The price point is intriguing for a widescreen 10.1 inch tablet. It uses an uncommon processor and although I like Asus laptops for value, their tablets were unknown to me.After using and more importantly enjoying this tablet, I am impressed and it is worthy for consideration for an Android tablet. It does have a few limits. The screen is very good but not great. I do have an iPad 3 and I felt it was just a tad less high def. And the pixel density does bear that out, it is 240. BUT there is plenty to like about the screen: very accurate colors and good color depth. It is a very good screen especially at the price. But not great.Performance: Very quick web surfing, very quick download and install of apps. Video apps: not as responsive as web surfing but still very enjoyable. Netflix, Watch ESPN, HBO Go all work well. But there are times when video seems to go down in quality which happens rarely with my iPad across the same exact wireless network. Games: good performance, and the screen is a little better with games than video.Speakers: very good tablet speakers and very good speaker control. There is an easily accessible speaker interface with different speaker modes, music, movie, talking, etc. These modes matter. Movie mode works great for videos and music for, well, music. While the volume isn't exceptional it is more than good enough and no distortion even at full volume. Much better speakers than the iPad.Build: VERY impressed. The MeMO pad feels good. In fact the textured back feels so good in the hand I really can't recommend getting a cover. It is that good. It is also lightweight for the size. I didn't think .2 of a lb or so can make a difference, it does. The MeMO is a pleasure to hold for long periods and use.Interface: I like it. You swipe downward from any screen and it brings up a lot of useful controls. You can build folders and various screens can have different functions and layouts. Unfortunately this is hard to learn about (more later). There are a number of Asus apps from drawing, to video production, to backup, etc.Good virtual keyboard, responsive and accurate.Camera: I don't use tablets for video or pictures. But I tried it out and the back camera takes decent pictures and video. If this is something you do you will not be disappointed.Cons: Although I like screen I am going to also put it on the con. The screen is the heart of any tablet to me. Tablets are visual machines. It is a very good screen. But if the Fire HDX lives up to its spec...that has to be a consideration. Video playback on various apps seems to degrade at times more than my iPad.Summary: Wow. Very few compromises, especially considering the price. This is an excellent value. Speaking of value, the 32GB is an absolute no brainer at $20 more. You get about 11.5 usable gigs with the 16GB. Micro SD is nice of course but good to have more system storage. If you want an Android tablet that does everything well, is pretty fast, and has an enjoyable if not top of the line screen, for a very competitive price, you should consider the MeMO pad. It really shows how overpriced iPads are, especially the non-retina mini which was and is a complete rip-off. Competition is paying off in the Android tablet market, there is a lot of value to be had, and the MeMO 10 is definitely value laden.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Sandra Hamilton "shamiltonky"
Reviews.Content: After doing some extensive research, I decided to purchase the Asus Memo.  The sound is superior, clear graphic, movies look sharp and clear .  And its  quick!  No problem loading apps from app store, Netflix, Hotmail, Angry Birds ect....  I have nothing bad to say about it.  I just love it.  It is easy to learn, as there is no real owners manual with it.  I was disappointing that it did not come with ear phones.  I think it is better than my kids Ipads, but I am not a Apple supporter either.  For the price, you cannot beat it.  I would highly recommend for the day to day user.  I also purchased the rooCase Asus Memo Pad FHD 10 case for it, very nice, nice fit.

Reviews.Title: ASUS MeMO Pad vs iPad Mini general impressions comparison review
Reviews.Author: Myra Schjelderup "Ignolopi"
Reviews.Content: I've had an iPad since they were released. I've used the original iPad, the iPad 2, and right now I have an iPad Mini. I've had the Mini for nearly a year and had nearly forgotten the pros and cons of a bigger device.This tablet looks and feels nice. It is a little larger than the standard iPad and lighter than the old iPads, but heavier than the iPad Airs. It is designed to be mostly used in landscape mode (since that is where the cameras are placed). The large screen is really nice for web browsing, since lots of websites don't optimize for tablets.I liked how smooth the touch response was on this device. It is seems as good as my iPad (I have tried other touch devices and none have matched up to the iPad yet for smoothness). There are only two buttons on the tablet, the power and sound buttons. Then there are 4 digital buttons; a button for a dock, a back button, home button, and all running apps view. Audio is nice and clear and the volume goes up pretty loud. The screen colors are nice and vibrant. Battery has been great so far.I tried comparing the Mini to this tablet in the web browser for speed and appearance. The Mini constantly loaded pages quicker, especially if they had lots of images. But once they were loaded there wasn't any difference between the devices.The cameras appear to be the same (ran a comparison, but also checked specs and they are both 5MP).This tablet runs Android Jellybean, which is currently one version behind. I am not going to try and compare Android vs iOS other than to say that they both have their pros and cons. I prefer the iOS, but I enjoy playing with Android.I spent a very short time once playing with a Samsung Galaxy, which was pretty awful. This tablet was so much better.In the end, I think this is a great option if you want an Android tablet.

Reviews.Title: Exceeded my expectation!  Great value for money.
Reviews.Author: Frank
Reviews.Content: It's a very light and decent tablet for the money.  The screen is crisp, and viewing angle is great.  I set the screen mode to vibrant and everything looks bright and vivid.  There are different sound modes to choose from - I chose the movie viewing mode.  The shell is sturdy and non slippery, so I'm using it without any case.  I mostly use this tablet for browsing the web, reading ebooks and emails - for which it does an excellent job.  It is lighter than my iPad2, and perhaps due to its unique weight distribution, it feels effortless to hold.  I use 'Next Issue' app to read magazines, and I found it to be a delightful experience.  With its HD screen, Netflix works great and it's stutter free with the couple of movies I played.  I do not play games, so no comment on game play.

Reviews.Title: ASUS MeMO Pad FHD 10
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have loved this from the moment I purchased it. At first I was a little disappointed because Adobe Flash player doesn't work on this but I knew that before purchasing it and I couldn't find a tablet that it did work on. But since that time Google play has had apps for me to download that has allowed me to play the things I love and watch show I love with out having to have the flash player so I am a happy camper. The price is awesome for what you get. I had done a lot of research before purchasing and I am very happy with the product.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful screen, light weight and nothing is slow
Reviews.Author: Mindy
Reviews.Content: I know that many people feel like iPads are worth the high prices but to me, when you have this ASUS Memo pad as an option why would you pay more just for a brand?Straight out of the box, I was very impressed with this. It was lightweight, and very sleek looking. (I know others thought the backing looked cheap but I didn't think so.) But the real "wow" factor came when the screen turned on. I was blown away by the clarity and crispness of the images. Movies looked great, photos looked vibrant. Everything popped and was very responsive.The battery life seems typical. One day, I spent the morning playing games on it and my son spent the afternoon on it. Needless to say, by 3pm it needed to be recharged again but that was not typical use. Normally, it would last throughout the day and I would charge it up at night.I've had no problems with any apps, either the ones it came with or the ones I downloaded via Amazon's app store. Nothing has been "slow" and everything seems to load perfectly.I only have two complaints: 1) This doesn't pick up my wireless as well as other things in the house. My Roku sits on the other side of the house, on a different floor and can still receive a healthy signal. This however does not. I have to move much closer to get reception. 2.) The sound buttons are inconveniently placed. I have a game that I play that requires the tablet be in a portrait orientation and since the volume buttons are on the bottom, they get inadvertently pressed very often.Despite these two complaints, I still feel like this is well worth the money and have been very pleased with it.

Reviews.Title: Amazing tablet.. 10/10
Reviews.Author: Alz1112
Reviews.Content: This is the best tablet out there for the price. Beautiful, smooth and runs cool all the time.-Powerful CPU, everything runs fast and smooth-Screen is beautiful, crisp-Battery life is great, 100% to 72% after like 2h and a half of use..(Netflix, browsing, gaming with 60-70% brightness)-Touch is very smooth and accurate, no lag/stutter-Speakers are amazing, loud and clear (best I've heard on a tablet)-Camera is good ( I don't use camera on tablet though)-Light, thin and easy to hold-White texture on the back looks beautifulI honestly don't have any dislikes about this tablet. For the price you won't find anything better or even close.

Reviews.Title: Definitely worth the $$
Reviews.Author: Kingmichaelg
Reviews.Content: I had the TF101 for almost 2 years and decided to buy the MeMO Pad.  Best decision ever.  The video, speed and battery life are awesome!  There were quite a few posts about the video however I think it rivals the best.  iPad & Samsung look out, this one might unseat you. :)

Reviews.Title: Excellent value for your tablet dollar!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This tablet gives any competitor a run for their money. With a large clear screen, excellent resolution, two cameras, and, most importantly, the ability to add on a microSD card, this is a very serious competitor to all the big names out there. The price is very agreeable. This is truly a powerhouse tablet, and the installed Android version is by far the best I have used so far. I seriously see no good reason to pay any more money for those other pretentious tablets that do not even allow to add on external memory. This tablet works very well for everything, from email to movies to internet search. No complaints whatsoever.

Reviews.Title: A Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: Olga Bezhanova
Reviews.Content: This tablet is a great alternative to an iPad and will please people who are used to working on an Android platform. I have recently been forced to abandon my Kindle Fire because its faulty charging outlet makes the device nearly impossible to use. This ASUS tablet allows me to use all of my favorite Android apps and read Kindle books.I've been using the tablet for a month, and can say that it hasn't disappointed me. The screen resolution is amazing, and watching movies and TV shows on the tablet is a great experience. The tablet is very intuitive and easy to use. I haven't experienced a single problem with it so far. The battery is vastly superior to Kindle Fire. The selection of apps on the Android platform is, of course, not as amazing as the apps you can find in the Apple Store but it is still big enough. I feel no temptation to buy an iPad now that I have this ASUS tablet.

Reviews.Title: I love my ASUS Memo!!!  Advanced User Review
Reviews.Author: Evile "Evile"
Reviews.Content: I love my Asus FHD 10!  I've been tinkering with tech since the 1990's and I've had a lot of cell phones, PDA's, MP3 players and computers, both Apple and the nonproprietary options.  Apple is one of my favs, I still rock the iPod Nano Gen 3, I gave my iPod touch to my son when I bought the Galaxy S3.  Anyway to the point, this has to be one of my favorite toys.  The CPU is snappy and responsive.  The internet access is so easy to set up and not have to worry about when going from place to place, as it automatically signs you into the nearest remembered network seamlessly.  The screen resolution is as good if not better than my LED 1080p televisions.  I can play with my tablet on my big TV through the HDMI micro port.  Movie watching is awesome because of the great picture and sound quality.  I love the back of the tablet and it doesn't feel cheap to me at all, in fact I prefer it, it is textured so it doesn't fall out of my hands, it is high quality durable plastic, not cheap like someone else had mentionedIand the speakers are in a position that is hard to cover with your hands while holding unlike most tablets.  It looks and operates like a tiny laptop.  I have capital tunnel so I can't really use a computer any longer, so the ability to swype is awesome.  Of course I could do this and more on my cell phone, but a 4.5" screen is not optimal for work use.  I'm a contractor, so it is easy to use for my business with a credit card processing attachment.  I can't think of anything I don't like.  It doesn't have a data connection, but that's why I have a hotspot on my phone!  You won't regret buying it unless you're a hard core gamer that tends to use a lot of RAM, because it is an acceptable fast game play; not what gamers prefer.  But I like my Candy Crush, Dragon Story, and word games, and for this purpose it is perfect game play experience.

Reviews.Title: Exploring uses and accessories for the ASUS MeMO FHD 10
Reviews.Author: Machodoc
Reviews.Content: THE VENDOR"The Nerds" offered the best prices that I could find, fast shipping, and excellent service all around.  HIGHLY recommend them!!THE PRODUCTI can't say how this tablet compares to others because I haven't tried any others that are supposed to be comparable to this.  I will say, though, that it's been excellent for my needs.  There are quite a few apps available for it--including a free suite of tools that are somewhat similar to MSOffice, but work with Android--that I use regularly.  I've got a lot of books in PDF format  (most free!) stored on my tablet, so I always have a reading library with me.  This tablet is far superior for that function, alone, than my Nook was ... and at about the same price ... but this does SOOO much more!While I didn't get this for the camera feature, the camera does a pretty good job in normal lighting conditions.  The display graphics are excellent.  I don't use it for games, but it's great for things like streaming media.  I learned a lesson many years ago, and bought the model of this tablet with the most internal memory, then added a large-capacity external SD card to it.  It's always good to have lots of storage space when using a camera, videos, and lots of large PDF files.One thing that came along right after I bought this was Google's "Chromecast" dongle for use as an interface between Internet services available on my WiFi network and my television.  This tablet works exceptionally well with that, acting sort of like a remote control unit for Netflix, Hulu, etc.  It won't stream anything directly from the tablet to the TV yet (Android doesn't support "tab casting" yet), but hopefully that's in the near future.  In the meantime, I can attach the tablet to my TV via an HDMI cable made to fit both units.  That works very well ... but there's still a cable between the two, even though I found one online that's thin, flexible, and long.One other very nice (and cheap) accessory that I got for it was a cable that allows me to attach USB thumb drives to the tablet via the micro USB port.  I ordered a couple of these through an online site for a couple of bucks each.  They work very well, so I can carry additional content with me without having to transfer it to the tablet (but I could, if I wanted to, using the file manager).  I haven't seen anyone promoting this option, but they should.  We all have USB drives lying around, and it's a convenient way to transport data.When I first bought the MeMO Pad, I thought that I needed to have a case with a keyboard, so I bought a universal-style case with a bluetooth keyboard.  The keyboard works fine, but I find that I seldom use it.  The case was unsatisfactory because it's clunky and it was hard to get to buttons and ports on the pad.  I bought a second case--one made just for this tablet, but without a keyboard.  It's excellent ... and much cheaper, and it came with a stylus and a magnetic closing system for the cover.  I still have the keyboard, from the other case, but seldom use it.  It's good to have around, though, when I'm travelling.It's been a learning experience getting used to how tablets work, but there's no huge learning curve with the Asus.  Very little of the usual new-computer frustration comes along with it.  Most stuff is pretty easy to figure out for those of us who don't like watching introduction presentations and reading books.  But for those rare times that there is a specific problem to sort out, Asus has a very good PDF manual online (which I downloaded to the tablet).  Most of my learning has come through exploring and experimenting, and that can be fun.

Reviews.Title: Blown Away! Great Tablet, Hands Down!
Reviews.Author: Natalie Herath
Reviews.Content: We have had the Asus Memopad 10.1 for a few days now. We tossed around the idea of which tablet to get for about a month. We traded in our iPad 1 as it could no longer be updated and was way out dated. We used the Amazon trade in program ( which I also recommend) and got an electronic credit toward another Amazon purchase.Before purchasing on amazon I took my husband to a retailer. There he was able to actually hold various tablets in his hands. The 7 and 8 inch tablets were too small for him. He of course picks up a 500 dollar tablet and starts to fall in love with it. I am cringing because all he does is web browse, play casino games, check Facebook and email. There is no need for him to have the most expensive tablet. But, where are going to find a 10.1 inch tablet that is affordable??.....yep Asus MemoPad! Perfect.Upon first using the memopad I was shocked at the initial setup. It walks you thru email set up.....easy! It comes pre loaded with all the necessary apps. The home screen is easy to navigate. There is a great note taking app that rivals Evernote, dare I even say it......The camera is fine. The video quality is acceptable for a tablet in this price point. As for all the stuff (bloatware) that is preloaded . . . That is still up for debate. The few that I clicked on seemed interesting and had its own function (card maker, video app, etc..) The 10.1 inch display is crisp, clear and stunning.In closing the MemoPad 10.1 was perfect for our situation! My husband is back to web browsing, Facebooking and sending emails with ease. I find myself always wanting to put my iPad 4s down and grab his MemoPad . . . . Ssshhhhhh don't tell anyone ;) buy it! You will love it! Buy it! We are glad we did.

Reviews.Title: Much better than expected!!
Reviews.Author: David G.
Reviews.Content: Amazing screen resolution, the sd card slot a plus, amazing sound, speakers on left and right side. Great battery life.

Reviews.Title: Good value for your money
Reviews.Author: Prism
Reviews.Content: This ASUS MeMO Pad FHD 10 is a good buy for your money, especially compared to what is on the market today. It is light and thin. The button placement if very user friendly. The screen is crisp and bright and the touchpad is very responsive. The processor is fast even when I have multiple windows open.  The micro SD slot is at a good placement and allows for the memory to be expanded to 32 GB. The battery life is excellent. The wi-fi connects easily without any problems. It also connects flawlessly to my bluetooth wireless keyboard.  The only con I have found is that the accessories (screen protector, cases) are hard to come by and the selection is slim.  I am hoping that as the popularity increases, I will have more choices in that area.

Reviews.Title: Great first time or replacement tablet
Reviews.Author: Larry
Reviews.Content: I ordered this to replace my 2 year old Motorola Xoom.  I was looking for a model similar in specs and was pleasantly surprised with this model.  I do presentations and wanted HDMI output, not found on many tablets.HDMI Out works flawlessly and allows you to keep continuous charge supplied to the Tablet while viewing the Tablet on your tv.After receiving the tablet, I had a couple questions and contacted ASUS support, spoke to a live rep who answered my questions - tremendous!It also has a microSD card slot so you can add additional storage to your tablet ... something most alternative Android tablets don't have.I would recommend this.

Reviews.Title: First-time Android tablet user reacts...
Reviews.Author: Diane Kistner
Reviews.Content: I've used a Chromebook, I've used various Kindles, but this is my first experience with a tablet. The Android OS is still pretty alien to me, and I'm still knocking around in it, discovering how it works. So it's probably not fair to review the tablet itself based on my own inexperience with the OS. But this tablet is high resolution, easy on the eyes, and amply large. I love that it senses the ambient lighting and adjusts automatically, because my Kindles don't do that and I have to take the brightness up and down manually.One thing I don't like about it is that it does not use Flash so you can't play anything that requires Flash. Any attempts to add Flash give you messages that Google or Adobe have decommissioned Flash and will not use it. I spent several hours nosing around in the forums looking for a solution, and even found some cautions that I could hurt my tablet by trying to install a Flash player, so I didn't do it. Sure, geeks and power users may laugh at this, but I don't want to mess with it. But what this means is that I cannot watch Amazon Prime movies on this tablet, which is a real bummer. In the forums I found discussions about this; it's apparently a problem with Amazon, not anybody else. They have not developed an app to allow playing their instant videos on Android systems. Somebody said they were hoping an app would be out by 2014, but that there was no guarantee; that Amazon is probably trying to protect its Kindle market by not releasing an app. So my normally high estimation of Amazon is knocked down a peg for absence of an app. Hopefully they will rememdy this soon.The first thing I did was order a rooCase for it, but I discovered that the cut-out in the rooCase for the rear-facing camera vignetted photos and videos (imagine a black circle around the edges). So I took the plunge and ordered ASUS Official Folio Keyboard Case for MeMOPad Smart ME301 Series, and that's given me a completely different experience with this tablet. It feels more like my Chromebook, if a little less stable in my lap. I like the soft-touch ON button on the Folio keyboard case because, without it, it's kind of hard to turn on the tablet. There are a few Bluetooth connection issues with the Folio keyboard case, but that's for another review.One thing that is weird to me about this tablet is that you are not supposed to leave it plugged in to the charger. I'm used to leaving my Kindles plugged in overnight, but with the Asus tablet you're only supposed to leave it plugged in for eight hours at most. (And if you get the Folio keyboard case for it, you use the same charger for both, one after the other.) The screen is more responsive to touch than my Kindle Fire, but still there is sometimes a lag that I haven't quite gotten used to yet. I think it's like learning to drive a new car: you just have to get used to the way it handles, and then you can groove right on into it.It is definitely easier on the eyes than a 7" screen. Again, the auto-adjusting brightness is a major boon. I love that I can pick it up in the middle of the night, read or browse for a while, then close it up in its case (which auto-offs) and go back to sleep. I'm still not sure I'm in love with the whole tablet concept, but Google Voice definitely makes it easier to use it. For the money, I think this Asus offering is a very good value.

Reviews.Title: Just didn't work out.
Reviews.Author: Debra
Reviews.Content: I REALLY loved this table when I first got it.  After about three months one day the on/off switch just  stopped working.  Amazon graciously refunded my money and I bought another one just like it.  After a week the screen got glitchy so I gave  up and tried another  brand.

Reviews.Title: Amazing tablet!!!
Reviews.Author: Jo Morris
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love my ASUS MeMO Pad FHD 10! My husband bought it for me for Christmas! I am so happy that I didnt go with a iPad mini. It runs super smooth, has a brilliantly crystal clear screen picture and feels VERY WELL MADE (because it is!)Pros-Crystal Clear HD Picture-Fast charging (even in use it charges pretty fast)-Bluetooth to multiple devices-Great Wifi connection-Battery lasts about 8.5 to 9.5 hrs and thats with CONSTANT music, video, game, reading, Facebook, budgeting use-Smooth running Android-Very light considering how well made it is-Durable-The back has basically a non-slip grip on it-Lound clear speakersConsThe only SMALL con I have is if you are using the tablet in portrait position - the volume button will be on the bottom but I dont change my volume much so that doesnt really bother me and shouldnt be a reason that you pass on such an amazing deal!This tablet is well worth the money. There is a case here on Amazon that you can get that comes with a Bluetooth keyboard for $35! You can also get a BLuetooth wireless mouse for it! I personally bought the Fosman Anti-Glare (Matte) Screen Protector for it. It fits perfect! There is a port to add a mico SD card. There is also a front and rear camera. They are both pretty clear and take good pictures. I use Skype a lot to talk with my cousin and I have yet to have a problem with it. Although, you are unable to  do other things while using Skype Video call becase it will shut your video off but you can still see the other person you are talking to in a little box on the screen. You can turn your video back on when you pull up your Skype window.Overall, I am absolutely pleased with my Christmas present! My husband picked the perfect one for me! I can do everything I need to! Makes it easier to take my tablet in my case than having to carry my laptop around! I bet itd be perfect for schooling or college!Case I bought: B00DLZWBS0Screen Protector: B00FASVSYE

Reviews.Title: My First Android Device and I am very Happy with It
Reviews.Author: M. Hanna
Reviews.Content: I've been using Windows on my computers since the very first versions. My current PC is a  Lenovo Yoga 13, which is a very powerful #Intel2in1 running Windows 8. I've had a number of iPhone versions.I also have a 1st generation Kindle Fire. I would never give up my PC or my smartphone, but I'm glad I got this tablet and I am now a fan of #IntelTablets.I wasn't sure what to expect when I got a tablet running Android and I do not have another Android device to compare. I've had this tablet for almost 2 months now, so I have a fairly good impression of what I can do with it. I I have found out that for most common tasks, I use this tablet as my first choice.Email:  I subscribe to way too many emails, so my inbox fills up quickly. Sometimes I take a quick look at email on my phone, but for real work on my email I prefer to use this tablet or my PC. If I'm not already using my PC, I reach for the tablet. The tablet is light and easier to handle than the Yoga, even though the Yoga is light for a convertible. If you write a lot of long emails, you might want to get out the PC or add a Bluetooth keyboard, but the built in keyboard and word suggestions make it easy to use. Winner:  TabletFacebook:  I use the phone a lot when my tablet isn't handy. But my first choice is the tablet unless I am already on my PC. The Facebook app won't let you adjust font size like you can do on your browser, so if you have bad eyes, you might choose a PC first. However, photos and videos that people share take advantage of the large screen size on the tablet. Winner:  TabletGames:  I don't play many PC games, so I'm talking about the games that you might play on Facebook or through a phone or tablet app. My example here is Candy Crush, but there are loads of games that you could get via Google Play or Amazon that will run fine on this tablet. I haven't ran into any compatibility issues yet. If I want to play Candy Crush on my PC, I have to open Facebook and then open the game. The process is time consuming. Opening the game on the tablet just seems simpler and it automatically takes full advantage of my screen size. Winner:  TabletCamera:  You can see by the specifications that you get a decent camera on this tablet. However, I haven't gotten used to holding up a tablet this large for taking photos. Don't get me wrong, you CAN take great photos and videos with the tablet, but I find myself using my iPhone for photos and videos because it feels better to hold the smaller device in my hands. Winner:  Phone (or a compact camera.)Reading:  My wife and I have a large and growing library of Kindle books. The Kindle app for Android works flawlessly. This tablet's large screen and light weight make it my first choice for reading books. I also have several books on my Olive Tree Bible Study app that I use on my phone and PC. I have been using my PC when I'm doing serious study so I can have multiple applications open, but for reading verses and having study notes open at the same time, the big screen on the tablet is more than adequate. So my favorite reading device is the tablet.Composing documents, making presentations, spreadsheets, and other office tasks. For now nothing beats a PC running Windows. I don't hesitate to boot up the Yoga for the heavy-duty tasks and PC games for Windows. It only takes what feels like 3 seconds to boot up, so time is not an issue. It's just that I like the smaller, lighter tablet best for tasks that a tablet can easily handle.BOTTOM LINE:  I am sold on the capabilities of this tablet and the Android OS for most of my everyday computing. Unless I don't have my tablet with me, this is the device I reach for first.You can see a boring video of me using some of the apps at [...]If you're really a glutton for punishment you can see unboxing the new tablet at [...]

Reviews.Title: Very nice product
Reviews.Author: Leanna
Reviews.Content: My husband  loves the ease of using this item, wish it had come with some written istructions, but he's managing, my husband is not a computer savey person, he's new to the electric world.

Reviews.Title: Not holding charging.
Reviews.Author: Ram
Reviews.Content: I used this product hardly for two months. Now it is not charging. I charged it for 2 days, Still it is showing 25% only.Now the speakers not working. There is no sound.

Reviews.Title: Excellent in every category - video review
Reviews.Author: Dave CR "Dave"

Reviews.Title: Awesome tablet!!!
Reviews.Author: kkamalx
Reviews.Content: I had bought Ramos W27 Pro before this, The screen quality was not good so I returned it, then I bought Contixo/ZTO tablet. Had so many issues with that, they replaced and sent a new tablet, same issues. Not to mention no Manufacturer support at all, don't even know who makes that tablet, you only deal with the seller AAA Mart. Returned it, and each time lost $20 in shipping plus the $10 restocking fee. So in total $229 + the $50 in shipping back and forth, so the tablet costed me $280, read my review on that tablet and get the details. before you fall into the trap. Finally came to my senses, and ordered Asus, I am tell you I am so glad I did. The screen quality is amazing, the tablet is fast comes with 2GB of RAM, dual 1.6Ghz Intel. 16GB of internal Storage. It rates very well on Antutu, mine is coming out close to 22,000 points. The best part costed me only $249!!! Amazing deal I have to say and very very good quality. So please do not fall into the trap of cheap Chinese tablets, they are not that cheap if you want good screen, they will also cost you $200-$270. Instead order this or Samsung.Update: 12/11/2013I have had this tablet now for 2 weeks, I absolutely love it. The pic quality is amazing, sound is great. Wifi is fast and i have played all sorts of games on this tablet and it is flawless and fast. I am very impressed by battery life.  Its light weight and durable.  If you can't afford a Galaxy Note or Tab then this is same quality as Galaxy Tab and better in many ways. Still less price, plus Asus keeps its tablet very up to date with all android versions. My verdict is a buy.

Reviews.Title: Useless
Reviews.Author: Aditya S.
Reviews.Content: So this is my Dad's 60th birthday gift. Wonderful. Especially the 10 inch screen because he can't see that well. It works well for the first 2 months (I gave it to him in February 1st week) - he loves the emailing, reading and playing Sudoko! Voila! Stops working in March. We tried the charging thing that some people had, worked again briefly, stopped again! Now, its not been working for a few weeks, but we just haven't had the time to follow up for this. Tried the charging, tried holding the power button, zip! Really, in my book if something completely stops working in a month or two of purchase, its basically junk and should be replaced. The moment I get back from travelling, I am going to contact ASUS about a replacement/fix whatever. I've bought ASUS laptops before, which worked fine so this was completely unbelievable. Honestly, if I could return this I would and just get an apple with extended warranty. At least there's less stress in that.Really disappointed ASUS.

Reviews.Title: Very nice!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: The HD, sound, speed, touch sensitivity, and price are outstanding. I highly recommend this device if you are upgrading from an older pad and do not wish to pay an outlandish price for the premium devices, whether it be Android or iOS!  I have had a Nexus 7 and a HP TouchPad and this device blows them both out of the water. My wife has an older iPad so I cannot compare the graphics to the newer models but you will not be disappointed with the screen resolution and HD of this Asus.

Reviews.Title: so far so good
Reviews.Author: Damon
Reviews.Content: After quite a bit of research and looking at a looooottttt of feedback I decided to go with this tablet. I am a 38yo man that travels for work and I wanted a tablet that I could put workout videos on and be able to get on the internet in my hotel room without having to drag my laptop around with me. I'm not a gamer so I cant really speak to how good it is for that, but I'm sure it's fine. I am not one that has to have the newest electronics out there and so far for me this is perfect. It is half the price of the upper end tablets and as far as I can tell does all the same things. The screen and picture are great. I will mention that this is my first tablet so as far as comparing this to the other ones is limited to the ones I played with in the store. Those might have had brighter screens or faster processors, but unless they were sitting side by side you would never know the difference. I've only had this for a week, but so far I am very happy with it.If you are like me and don't have to have the most expensive electronics to feel good about yourself this tablet will be perfect for you. Actually after the extensive research I did on tablets, I would rate this right up there with the top of the line tabs for less than half the cost.

Reviews.Title: Highly recommended
Reviews.Author: Biddin4mine
Reviews.Content: I have the tablet for about 4 weeks now, and it is very nice, I really like it.It is super thin, well built, and the battery last 10 hours or more in use.  Which is pretty amazing.The resolution is second to none, and operating system, works well.It would be nice if it came with a case, but that is all I could say that could be better.I am thinking of buying a second one for my wife.

Reviews.Title: Can't do better for the price.
Reviews.Author: Robert DeLisle
Reviews.Content: I spent a lot of time evaluating. Does this thing hitch occasionally? Yes, mostly on pdfs, but so do all the samsung tabs and notes, and ipads, and everything else. Hell my computer even does. Is it the prettiest thing? No. The screen has a high enough resolution your eyes can't track a difference, battery life is good, the memory is upgradeable. It is 95% of the tablet you get for 400 dollars for 230. I personally don't think that last 5% is worth 170 bucks. The only way I would have liked it better is if it were carried by best buy and I could get the accidental coverage through them and never have to worry about the thing breaking for two years.

Reviews.Title: Great display and speedy performance
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "eyegor"
Reviews.Content: The Asus MeMO Pad FHD 10 is an nicely engineered android 4.2 based 10 inch tablet. I also own an iPad 3 and a 2013 Nexus 7 and am favorably impressed by the MeMO Pad. The aspect ratio is more like a wide screen TV than the boring 4:3 of the iPad and the display looks crisp and sharp when streaming movies. The tablet is lightweight and has the usual micro USB port, a micro HDMI port, a headphone jack and a micro SD card slot.  The micro SD card slot is especially welcome since the Nexus 7 lacks that feature entirely.Android 4.2 isn't the newest OS out there, but it's still very recent and is quite similar to the Nexus 7, but adds some Asus specific apps and an icon in the lower left of the screen that pops up some simple apps. The Asus supplied apps seem to work just fine, but I'd like to maintain compatibility with my other android as much as possible, so I'm sticking with the google apps.Battery life seems quite good and the smart sleep feature greatly cuts down on battery drain for times when I forget to plug it in for charging.The back of the tablet is a textured plastic which makes it feel secure when holding it, but you can still see a bit of flex in the body of the tablet when handling it, so I added a case to make it a bit less fragile feeling.I'm very impressed with the MeMO Pad, but am not surprised either. Asus has been building high quality systems, laptops and tablets (including the Nexus 7) for years and their experience shows.Negatives:NonePositives:great screen, speed and battery life. Wifi seems good, but I've not tried it much in extreme cases. I love having an micro SD slot too.While I appreciate a universally adopted port for charging and tethering, micro USB connectors are absolutely awful when compared to the Lightening adapter of the newer iPads and iPhones. I'd love to see a new, easier to use standard someday.

Reviews.Title: Exceeded my expectations!
Reviews.Author: audiophizile
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing tablet. The screen is sharp, clear and is bright enough for all use but direct sunlight. WiFi range is excellent compared to Acer ultra book, note 2, or gs3. It is impressively fast for everything I have tested. The stock launcher is lacking but easily fixed by installing nova launcher. Chrome is also not great compared to the standard browser and boat browser but again easy fix by not using it. Sound is great. Some of the built in apps are nice but others feel like average bloat. I do like the floating window feature quite a bit. I waited for this to come out as it seemed like a great value and it actually far exceeded my expectations for a 10" tablet at this price point. You can get tablets as fast for cheaper but you'd have to go down to a 7". If a 10" is what you're looking for and don't want to spend ~$450-500 this is the best tablet I've seen. Highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Great addition to the family
Reviews.Author: Dana G.
Reviews.Content: I already own and use a Kindle FIre HD7".  When I got the chance to try out this ASUS MeMO pad, I jumped on it because it's a little bit bigger.  I also have been thinking of getting an iPad, but haven't gotten to that point yet.  This MeMO pad is an Android device.  Pretty much the only thing I am not in love with about this thing is that it is a bit confusing to operate if you are an Apple product user.  I have a MacBook, iPhone, and several other Mac products, all which operate similarly.  This Android thing is cool, but there is an adjustment period that should be taken into consideration if you are coming from an Apple interface.The best thing for me, in comparing this product to the Kindle Fire 7" is the screen size.  The viewing screen measures 8.5" x 5.5", which is quite a bit larger than the viewing screen on my Kindle, which measures 3.75" x 6".  Sure I like my Kindle because it is very handy to carry around, so I wouldn't trade that in for this, I love this in addition to my Kindle.  This MeMO pad is just  a great addition to my family because of how we use it.  My nine year old daughter reads online comics that I subscribe to for her every morning at breakfast.  ([...]  Before this pad, she would use my Macbook and I would flip out when she got food all over my keyboard, mousepad, etc.  Now that we have this bigger tablet, she can read her comics on it.  I bought a case that came with a stylus to go with the pad, so it's all decked out.  I was surprised to see so many cases on the market for it, since it seems there are about a thousand different tablets on the market right now.  Oh by the way, this MeMO pad comes with a black plastic easel-type thing that lets you prop up the tablet and read it easily.  I didn't see it until after I ordered my case, because it matched the black plastic packing material inside of the box.I am not going to give you a super-techie review, but an "everyday person's review".  The tablet itself has great sound, and very vibrant screen color.  Ear buds are not included with the tablet.  I haven't watched Netflix on it, so I can't comment about watching movies or television shows on it, but I think it would be great.  I downloaded the Amazon Kindle app on it, and it is an awesome way to read the books I have purchased for myself and my kids.  We are not all fighting for the Kindle Fire 7", now we have options!  One thing ASUS could improve upon is the charger.  The cord is just under 3 feet long, which is not very long at all.  I would prefer at least a 4' cord.  And the plug ends don't fold down into the end of the plug box like the Kindle charger, it just sticks out.  At least this is a generic micro USB charger, so I have plenty of other options lying around my house that are longer.

Reviews.Title: Very happy so far.
Reviews.Author: J. S. King
Reviews.Content: I've had this tablet for about 3 weeks now and still finding new things each day.  So far, nothing I wasn't warned about and nothing that makes me feel shorted.  I'm finding it to be a good tablet at a fantastic price.  In my book, that makes it an excellent value.  Don't know how many of the negative comments were due to receiving a bad unit, being overly critical or not knowing how to operate the unit.  Here is my take on some of the issues that other reviewers found objectionable:No user manual included:  Couldn't believe some people had trouble finding a manual on line, but actually, if you go to the app called My Library (some referred to as "bloatware"), there is a copy of the complete user manual, Alice in Wonderland and Pride and Prejudice.Bloatware:  I'll concede that an app called Mirror that simply turns on the front facing camera and nothing else has limited usefulness, but how much memory is that actually using?  According to the internal storage summary, there is just over 11GB of internal memory available.  All of the "bloatware" takes up 242MB, and at least I found much of that to be at least somewhat useful.Battery life:  My experience was that after the initial 8 hour charge, I got about 7.5 hours of use with 10% power remaining.  There are two standard power saving settings and one that can be customized for your use, so I believe that, under the right conditions, Asus' estimate of "up to 10hrs" is achievable.  I get the idea that the charging system on this tablet may be a little fragile, as they warn you not to leave it on the charger for extended periods of time.  I generally charge overnight.Display:  My only complaint is a small one.  The display could possibly be just a little brighter for outdoor use.  It is plenty bright enough for any indoor situations, even bright lighting.  The resolution is quite good.  The Galaxy Note and the iPad are noticeably more vivid, but you are looking at $200 - $300 more.  The Nexus is slightly better.  Maybe Asus sacrificed a little screen brightness to gain battery life.Processor:  Can't really comment other than that the high res pictures take a second or two to fully render, so this may cause some problems for gamers.  Probably depends on the game, but I don't use the tablet for that.  There are some good technical comparisons on the web if that is a concern to you.Durability:  I must say that stories of the screens spontaneously cracking were disconcerting.  Didn't find much to support it when I Googled it.  I purchased the Minisuit Classic Flip Stand Case from Amazon and am very happy with it.  Also put a screen protector on it.Camera:  It takes a nice picture in bright light  That's about all I can say.Audio:  It does have pretty good sound quality through its own speakers.  It is not Blue Ray so don't expect it.  It's just good enough that it doesn't sound like a transistor radio (for those that remember them).  There is a built in mixer to fine tune the sound a little.  Max volume could afford to be a little higher.  Might be a problem using in a very noisy environment without ear buds.Screen responsiveness:  Someone recently commented about a lag in the key board.  I have experienced this, too, but have experienced it on other virtual keyboards, too.  It doesn't present a problem for me.  I have actually begun using the voice commands more frequently.  I have never used voice recognition software that typed this accurately.  Even with the screen protector on, the screen has been quite responsive to touch.I have rated it 4 stars based on its own merits.  If I were rating it compared to other 10" tablets in the $250 range, it would get 5+ stars.

Reviews.Title: Very good product. (Updated)
Reviews.Author: Quang Nguyen
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my mom. She likes it a lot. These are a few things she notices since started using this:Pros:_ Long battery life._ New android version are easy to use.._ Fast internet surfing,_ Plays HD video smoothlyCons:_ A few bloat-ware but can easily be disable._ T̶h̶e̶ ̶f̶r̶o̶n̶t̶ ̶c̶a̶m̶e̶r̶a̶ ̶w̶o̶n̶'̶t̶ ̶w̶o̶r̶k̶ ̶w̶h̶e̶n̶ ̶i̶ ̶u̶s̶e̶ ̶o̶o̶V̶o̶o̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶s̶o̶m̶e̶ ̶o̶t̶h̶e̶r̶ ̶v̶i̶d̶e̶o̶ ̶c̶a̶l̶l̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶s̶o̶f̶t̶w̶a̶r̶e̶s̶.̶ ̶(̶T̶a̶k̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶p̶i̶c̶t̶u̶r̶e̶s̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶r̶e̶c̶o̶r̶d̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶v̶i̶d̶e̶o̶s̶ ̶a̶r̶e̶ ̶o̶k̶)̶.̶Update May 25, 2014: After a firmware update from ASUS this morning, the front camera now works perfectly with every video calling app i use. And i'm confident to give it 5 stars. Good work ASUS!

Reviews.Title: My first Tablet. Love it.
Reviews.Author: Jeff Arritt
Reviews.Content: I looked at others and live with an apple nut. Love the quick connection and loading of websites and videos. Watched ESPN basketball game that was not available on our area cable. Not solely why I bought it, but, that nearly justified the purchase with that one games experience.The apple/ipod nut could only ask...."How did you do that?" ASUS MeMO10 FHD Andriod! Enough said

Reviews.Title: ASUS MeMO Pad FHD 10 ME302C-A1-BL 10.1-Inch 16GB Tablet (Blue)
Reviews.Author: Richard Cook
Reviews.Content: The tablet arrived sooner than promised and was easy to set up after a little research.  I'm new to tablets (don't have a laptop) and found the included  instructions to be very minimal.  I did find a ASUS PDF online which answered all my setup and use questions.  I'm happy with this ASUS tablet and am looking forward to using it as a substitute for my desk top and while traveling.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Tablet !!!!
Reviews.Author: Arthur
Reviews.Content: Excellent budget priced alternative to both the Ipad and Samsung products.  Loaded with features and useful apps.  No issues adding my music and books and transferring them between it and my laptop was a breeze.  Video quality blew me away, though the default video settings had to be altered to suit my taste, this was easy to accomplish.  Sound can be optimized for music, games or voice.  No issues with gameplay and touch response was good.  I appreciate being able to move files so easily and the micro SD card reader means virtually limitless storage capacity (just swap cards).
